L1_summary_of_paper: This integrative review consolidates the strategic cognition (SC) literature from 1993–2007 and proposes a multi-level framework linking antecedents (environmental, organizational, decision-specific, individual) to cognitive structures (organizational identity, strategy frames, organizational routines), cognitive processes (strategy formulation, implementation, strategic change, organizational learning), and outcomes (process outcomes, strategic actions, economic outcomes). The paper synthesizes five empirical streams—(1) antecedents and outcomes of strategy frames, (2) determinants and consequences of strategy formulation, (3) cognitive construction of competitive/industry dynamics, (4) determinants and consequences of strategy implementation, and (5) antecedents and outcomes of organizational identity—classifying (1–3) as well-developed and (4–5) as emerging. It clarifies key concepts (e.g., sensemaking/sensegiving, issue selling), debates (e.g., stability vs. fluidity of identity; homogeneity vs. heterogeneity of frames), and operationalizations (causal maps, text analysis, surveys, ethnography), and outlines a research agenda emphasizing multi-level linkages, better measurement, and tighter integration with core strategy theories. Main conclusion: cognition is causal to strategy via how actors notice, interpret, and routinize, shaping actions and performance through attention filters and interpretive processes.
M3_unit_of_analysis_element: Other: Strategic cognition structures (identity, frames, routines)
Other: Strategic cognition processes (sensemaking, sensegiving, scanning, decision making, issue selling, strategic change, learning)
A1_citation: Narayanan, V. K., Zane, L. J., & Kemmerer, B. (2011). The cognitive perspective in strategy: An integrative review. Journal of Management, 37(1), 305–351. https://doi.org/10.1177/0149206310383986
C3_metric_detail: Uncertainty and ambiguity are treated as inherent to strategic contexts and as triggers for sensemaking; they are discussed rather than standardized/measured across studies.
D5_data_sources: Prior peer-reviewed empirical and conceptual studies synthesized in the review

E2_effect_directions.Other: Process outcomes: Other: Conceptual synthesis (no effect size/direction estimated)
E2_effect_directions.Other: Strategic actions: Other: Conceptual synthesis (no effect size/direction estimated)
E2_effect_directions.Other: Economic performance: Other: Conceptual synthesis (no effect size/direction estimated)

F2_risk_of_bias_notes: Scope is limited to cognition-explicit strategy studies in major journals; exclusion of method/tool-only papers may omit relevant measurement advances.
G1_construct_mapping_note: Maps antecedents → (identity, frames, routines) & (formulation, implementation, change, learning) → process/strategic/economic outcomes, specifying links and levels.
G4_unifying_props_drafts: SC mediates links from antecedents to strategic and economic outcomes via attention/interpretation filters.
Structure–process interactions (e.g., frames × sensemaking) condition action timing and repertoire.
Environmental dynamism shifts the value of frame complexity vs. focus and of routine elasticity.
NA_reason_if_any: Conceptual integrative review; no original empirical identification or causal estimation.
I1_mechanism_statements: Organizational identity bounds feasible strategy sets and coordinates action but can induce cognitive inertia.
Strategy frames filter and structure information, guiding attention allocation and decision criteria in formulation.
Organizational routines embed scripts that economize attention and channel implementation behaviors.
Sensegiving (top) and issue selling (middle) co-produce shared interpretations that shape execution trajectories.
Scanning and sensemaking jointly convert ambiguity into actionable interpretations that determine timing and content of moves.
I3_theoretical_propositions: Strong, coherent identity enhances coordination yet risks rigidity; identity fluidity can be adaptive in high-velocity contexts.
Frame complexity promotes flexibility in fast clockspeed environments; frame focus aids persistence in slow clockspeed environments.
Issue selling effectiveness increases when framed to match dominant logic and when organizational capacity to respond is high.
J1_main_findings_summary: Proposes a comprehensive SC framework connecting antecedents, cognitive structures/processes, and outcomes across levels.
Identifies five empirical streams and distinguishes well-developed (frames, formulation, industry cognition) from emerging (implementation, identity).
Details operationalizations for SC elements (causal maps, text analysis, surveys, ethnography) and highlights measurement gaps.
Surfaces key debates (identity stability; TMT cognitive homogeneity vs. heterogeneity; enacted vs. perceived environment).
Sets an agenda for multi-level designs, standardized measures, and stronger causal identification in future SC research.
K1_contribution_summary: The review elevates strategic cognition as a distinct, integrative lens in strategy, organizing fragmented work into a multi-level framework that links antecedents to cognitive structures and processes and, in turn, to strategic and economic outcomes; it consolidates measures, clarifies debates, and sets a forward-looking research program.
